meanings.def: not one of a group of people or things; not any
examples: None of these pens works/work.
We have three sons but none of them lives/live nearby.
We saw several houses but none we really liked.
Tickets for Friday? Sorry we've got none left.
He told me all the news but none of it was very exciting.
‘Is there any more milk?’ ‘No, none at all.’
(formal) Everybody liked him but none (= nobody) more than I.
None of the work was done.
None of the trains is/​are going to London.
None of her family has/​have been to college.
I offered to pay but he was having none of it.
They pretended to be enthusiastic about my work but then suddenly decided they wanted none of it.
None but he knew the truth.

meanings.def: used to emphasize who or what somebody/something is, when this is surprising
examples: Her first customer was none other than Mrs Obama.
I offered to pay but he was having none of it.
They pretended to be enthusiastic about my work but then suddenly decided they wanted none of it.
None but he knew the truth.

idioms.def: used to emphasize who or what somebody/something is, when this is surprising
examples: Her first customer was none other than Mrs Obama.

meanings.def: used with the and a comparative to mean ‘not at all’
examples: She told me what it meant at great length but I'm afraid I'm none the wiser.
He seems none the worse for the experience.

meanings.def: used with too and an adjective or adverb to mean ‘not at all’ or ‘not very’
examples: She was looking none too pleased.
